elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of CuX2 (X = NO3, Cl, Br, I) with tetra-pyridyl-functionalized calix[4]­arene at 130 °C afforded four novel coordination polymers, {[(CuNO3)2L]­·MeOH} n (1), [(CuCl2)­L0.5] n (2), [(Cu3Br3)­L] n (3), and [(Cu3I3)­L] n (4), where L = 25,26,27,28-tetra­[(3-pyridylmethyl)­oxy]­calix[4]­arene. All the products were characterized by infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and powder X-ray diffraction. Crystal structure analysis reveals that 1 holds a one-dimensional (1D) double-chain constructed by mononuclear [Cu­(NO3)] units and L linkers, while 2 features a 1D chain and its bowl-shaped L ligands work as linkers to connect the dinuclear [Cu2Cl4] units. Compounds 3 and 4 bear similar two-dimensional networks, in which each trinuclear [Cu3Br3]/[Cu3I3] unit works as a three-connecting node to connect its six equivalents by sharing L ligands. These results demonstrate that different anions have a significant effect on the final structure formation. Compounds 1–4 were employed as catalysts for the A3 coupling reaction under microwave irradiation. Notably, 3 showed the best catalytic properties for the synthesis of versatile propargylamines (yield up to 94% in only 10 min) from the A3 reaction of formaldehyde with a variety of alkynes and amines.

elements.content: Owing to the procedural simplicity and synthetic efficiency, one-pot multicomponent reactions (MCRs) have aroused wide concern in the past few decades, which provided a feasible synthetic strategy to access complex structures using rather simple starting materials by a one-pot method and exhibited high selectivity and atom economy. An increasing number of MCRs have been designed for the synthesis of versatile structures with high yield and simple operation. Among various MCRs, considerable attention has been paid to the catalytic coupling reaction of aldehyde, amine, and alkyne (so-called A3 coupling), as the main product propargylamine is the key and versatile intermediate to prepare many biologically active nitrogen-containing compounds. Therefore, it is important to explore an efficient catalyst with a simple procedure for the A3 coupling reaction.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Owing to the procedural simplicity and synthetic efficiency, one-pot multicomponent reactions (MCRs) have aroused wide concern in the past few decades, which provided a feasible synthetic strategy to access complex structures using rather simple starting materials by a one-pot method and exhibited high selectivity and atom economy. An increasing number of MCRs have been designed for the synthesis of versatile structures with high yield and simple operation. Among various MCRs, considerable attention has been paid to the catalytic coupling reaction of aldehyde, amine, and alkyne (so-called A3 coupling), as the main product propargylamine is the key and versatile intermediate to prepare many biologically active nitrogen-containing compounds. Therefore, it is important to explore an efficient catalyst with a simple procedure for the A3 coupling reaction.

elements.content: Over the past several decades, calix[4]­arene-based molecules have emerged as a class of molecular hosts due to their bowl-shaped cavity and ability to interact with various guest molecules. Recently, the calix[4]­arenes and their derivatives have also been utilized as potential molecular units to construct coordination polymers because of the easy modification and functionalization both on the lower and upper rims. Moreover, the calix[4]­arene core displays inherent advantageous features, such as preorganization, flexibility, and bulkiness skeleton, as well as its wide tolerance of functional groups and metals. As a consequence, by tethering particular transition metals on such a structure, the as-synthesized coordination polymers would be potential catalysts. The calix[4]­arene platform provides a peculiar arrangement for the binding/catalytic site in a complementary array to recognize/transform a potential substrate, which would be favorable for the design of versatile catalysts. Furthermore, owing to the presence of the well-defined cavity near the catalytic center, we envisioned that the calix[4]­arene-based coordination polymers could give high selectivity for the catalytic reaction.

Recently, the calix[4]arenes and their derivatives have also been utilized as potential molecular units to construct coordination polymers because of the easy modification and functionalization both on the lower and upper rims. Moreover, the calix[4]arene core displays inherent advantageous features, such as preorganization, flexibility, and bulkiness skeleton, as well as its wide tolerance of functional groups and metals. As a consequence, by tethering particular transition metals on such a structure, the as-synthesized coordination polymers would be potential catalysts. The calix[4]arene platform provides a peculiar arrangement for the binding/catalytic site in a complementary array to recognize/transform a potential substrate, which would be favorable for the design of versatile catalysts. Furthermore, owing to the presence of the well-defined cavity near the catalytic center, we envisioned that the calix[4]arene-based coordination polymers could give high selectivity for the catalytic reaction.

elements.content: Nowadays, it is widely acknowledged that microwave irradiation has great advantages over traditional heating because of its shorter reaction time, higher product yield, and lower energy consumption. Thus, our studies report microwave-assisted Cu­(I/II)-calix[4]­arene-based catalysis as an efficient catalytic platform for direct access to propargylamines. On the basis of the design, the Cu­(I/II) ion was chosen as an active site to catalyze the A3 reaction due to its high catalytic activity. The ligand tetra-pyridyl-functionalized calix[4]­arene, 25,26,27,28-tetra-[(3-pyridylmethyl)­oxy]­calix[4]­arene (denoted as L) was employed to assemble with copper salts, as its abundant aromatic rings would facilitate the substrates alkyne to approach the active site of Cu­(I/II) ion through π–π interactions between the substrates and the aromatic rings. Hence, four coordination polymers, {[(CuNO3)2L]­·MeOH} n (1), [(CuCl2)­L0.5] n (2), [(Cu3Br3)­L] n (3), and [(Cu3I3)­L] n (4), were synthesized by the assembly of L with CuX2 (X = NO3, Cl, Br, I), giving different structural architectures. Their catalytic activities were assessed by the microwave-assisted A3 coupling reaction. Interestingly, compound 3 exhibited the best catalytic properties for the synthesis of diverse propargylamines (yield up to 94% in only 10 min) from the A3 reaction.

elements.content: The reactions of alkyne (1.0 mmol), amine (1.2 mmol), HCHO (1.2 mmol), catalyst (0.001 mmol), and MeCN (10 mL) were conducted in a closed vessel containing under microwave power (80 W) at 100 °C. After that, the system was cooled to ambient temperature and the MeCN was removed by evaporation in a vacuum. By diluting with 8 mL of H2O, the residual mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 10.0 mL). The combined organic phases were treated to remove the solvent and further purified by column chromatography using petroleum ether/ethyl acetate as the eluent to give the corresponding products. These products were characterized by 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and high resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS).
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Studies

The reactions of alkyne (1.0 mmol), amine (1.2 mmol), HCHO (1.2 mmol), catalyst (0.001 mmol), and MeCN (10 mL) were conducted in a closed vessel containing under microwave power (80 W) at 100 °C. After that, the system was cooled to ambient temperature and the MeCN was removed by evaporation in a vacuum. By diluting with 8 mL of H2O, the residual mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 10.0 mL). The combined organic phases were treated to remove the solvent and further purified by column chromatography using petroleum ether/ethyl acetate as the eluent to give the corresponding products. These products were characterized by 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and high resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS).

elements.content: Reactions of L ligand with Cu­(NO3)2­·3H2O and CuX2 (X = Br, I) in different solvents (MeOH/DMF for 1, MeOH/DMF for 3 and DMF for 4) at 130 °C for 3 days afforded colorless crystals of 1 (44% yield), 3 (57% yield), and 4 (51% yield), respectively. Interestingly, for compounds 1, 3, and 4, Cu­(II) was reduced to Cu­(I), which may stem from the reduction of Cu­(II) mediated by the DMF decomposition products. Similarly, reactions of CuCl2·2H2O with L ligand in EtOH produced red crystals of 2 (47% yield). To verify the valence of copper in these compounds, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) investigations were carried out. In Figure S1b, the peaks of Cu 2p3/2 at ca. 932.1 eV in 1, 3, and 4 are attributed to Cu­(I). Comparing Cu 2p XPS spectra of 1, 3, and 4 with that of 2, the higher binding energy of the Cu 2p3/2 peak at 934.3 eV in 2 is assigned to Cu­(II), accompanied by the characteristic Cu­(II) shakeup satellite peaks (938–945 eV) at 942.9 and 940.7 eV.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthetic and Spectral Aspects

Reactions of L ligand with Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O and CuX2 (X = Br, I) in different solvents (MeOH/DMF for 1, MeOH/DMF for 3 and DMF for 4) at 130 °C for 3 days afforded colorless crystals of 1 (44% yield), 3 (57% yield), and 4 (51% yield), respectively. Interestingly, for compounds 1, 3, and 4, Cu(II) was reduced to Cu(I), which may stem from the reduction of Cu(II) mediated by the DMF decomposition products. Similarly, reactions of CuCl2⋅2H2O with L ligand in EtOH produced red crystals of 2 (47% yield). To verify the valence of copper in these compounds, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) investigations were carried out. In Figure S1b, the peaks of Cu 2p3/2 at ca. 932.1 eV in 1, 3, and 4 are attributed to Cu(I). Comparing Cu 2p XPS spectra of 1, 3, and 4 with that of 2, the higher binding energy of the Cu 2p3/2 peak at 934.3 eV in 2 is assigned to Cu(II), accompanied by the characteristic Cu(II) shakeup satellite peaks (938-945 eV) at 942.9 and 940.7 eV.

Compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Ibca. Its asymmetric unit contains half of [(CuNO3)2L] unit and one MeOH molecule. In a, each Cu center is three-coordinated by one O atom of one NO3 – anion and two pyridyl N atoms from one L ligand. A flattened cone conformation was formed in calix[4]­arene core of 1 (a). The mononuclear [Cu­(NO3)] subunit works as a 2-connected node to interconnect the L ligands, resulting in a one-dimensional (1D) [(CuNO3)2L] n double-chain (b).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

Compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Ibca. Its asymmetric unit contains half of [(CuNO3)2L] unit and one MeOH molecule. In a, each Cu center is three-coordinated by one O atom of one NO3 - anion and two pyridyl N atoms from one L ligand. A flattened cone conformation was formed in calix[4]arene core of 1 (a). The mononuclear [Cu(NO3)] subunit works as a 2-connected node to interconnect the L ligands, resulting in a one-dimensional (1D) [(CuNO3)2L] n  double-chain (b).

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2/n. Its asymmetric unit includes half of a [(Cu2Cl4)­L] unit. Each Cu­(II) atom is five-coordinated by three Cl– anions and two pyridyl N atoms from one L ligand, producing a distorted [CuN2Cl3] pentagonal pyramid coordination geometry (a). Similar to that in 1, a flattened cone conformation was also formed in the calix[4]­arene core of 2, and a parallel or sharply inclined position was observed for the opposed phenyl rings (a). Two [CuCl] subunits are connected by two μ2-Cl anions to form a dinuclear [Cu2Cl4] unit (b). The Cu1···Cu1A separations are 3.4847(10) Å. These [Cu2Cl4] units are also employed as 2-connected nodes to link L ligands through the N atoms of pyridyl arms, producing a 1D [(Cu2Cl4)­L] n chain (c).

elements.content: Both compounds 3 and 4 crystallize in the monoclinic space group Cc. Their asymmetric units include one [(Cu3Br3)­L] and [(Cu3I3)­L] unit, respectively, while the Cu atoms in 3 and 4 adopted different coordination geometries. For 3, Cu1 and Cu2 atoms adopt the same coordination geometries, which is coordinated by one pyridyl N atom from one L ligand and two μ2-Br atoms to complete the triangular geometries (a). The Cu3 atom is tetrahedrally coordinated by two pyridyl N atoms from L ligands and two μ2-Br atoms (a). For 4, each Cu center is bonded with μ2-I or μ3-I atoms and pyridyl N atoms from L ligands, resulting in the distorted [CuI3N]/[CuI2N2] tetrahedral coordination geometries (b). A flattened cone conformation was also formed in the calix[4]­arene core of 3 and 4, and parallel or sharply inclined position was observed for the opposed phenyl rings (a,b). As shown in c,d, the Cu1, Cu2, and Cu3 centers are interconnected by three μ2-Br atoms or one μ2-I and two μ3-I atoms to afford the trinuclear [Cu3Br3] and [Cu3I3] units, respectively. The Cu···Cu separations are in the range of 2.5604(12)–2.9101(12) Å and 2.4166(8)–2.8415(9) Å for 3 and 4. Furthermore, each [Cu3Br3] or [Cu3I3] unit in 3 and 4 connects its three equivalents by sharing L ligands to give 2D networks (e and Figure S3).

elements.content: To investigate the thermal stability, thermogravimetric (TG) measurements of 1–4 were conducted (Figure S4). In 1, the first weight loss of 2.46% (calculated 2.99%) at the temperature range of 35–240 °C is attributed to MeOH solvent molecules. After that, further heating led to gradual decomposition of the compound. For 2–4, TG analysis indicated that they are stable up to 255 °C (2), 295 °C (3), and 305 °C (4), and then they begin to decompose.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior

To investigate the thermal stability, thermogravimetric (TG) measurements of 1-4 were conducted (Figure S4). In 1, the first weight loss of 2.46% (calculated 2.99%) at the temperature range of 35-240 °C is attributed to MeOH solvent molecules. After that, further heating led to gradual decomposition of the compound. For 2-4, TG analysis indicated that they are stable up to 255 °C (2), 295 °C (3), and 305 °C (4), and then they begin to decompose.

elements.content: Copper­(I)/(II) complexes are fascinating not only for their interesting structures, but also for their catalytic application in many organic transformations. In order to assess the catalytic utility of copper compounds 1–4 and further determine the best reaction conditions to afford propargylamines with excellent yields, a series of A3 coupling reactions have been performed under microwave irradiation using formaldehyde, amine, and alkyne in the presence of copper catalysts 1–4.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Applications

Copper(I)/(II) complexes are fascinating not only for their interesting structures, but also for their catalytic application in many organic transformations. In order to assess the catalytic utility of copper compounds 1-4 and further determine the best reaction conditions to afford propargylamines with excellent yields, a series of A3 coupling reactions have been performed under microwave irradiation using formaldehyde, amine, and alkyne in the presence of copper catalysts 1-4.

elements.content: Initially, to optimize the reaction conditions, ethynylbenzene, formaldehyde, and morpholine were chosen as the model substrates (). Various copper catalysts (0.001 equiv) were tested at 100 °C in MeCN under microwave irradiation (, entries 1–4), resulting in the desired products with the yields of trace, 62%, 91%, and 78%, respectively. To ascertain the role of the structural features in catalysis, the electrospray ionization–mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) spectra of 1–4 were recorded. As shown in Figure S5, the base peak at 1640.0834 in the spectra of 1 is attributed to the [CuL2]+ fragment, in which the catalytic sites Cu­(I) are buried in the packing arrangement formed by L ligands that adopt the up and down modes (b), making the alkyne molecules difficult to approach the catalytic sites Cu­(I), while, for 2–4, the peaks of the spectra at 1812.5001, 1138.8334, and 1232.9167 are attributed to [(Cu2Cl3)­L2]+ (2), [(Cu3Br2)­L]+ (3), and [(Cu3I2)­L]+ (4) fragments, respectively. In the above fragments, the catalytic sites of Cu­(I/II) are exposed, as the L ligands arranged as single layer with the bowl-shaped fashions (c and Figures S6–S7), which may facilitate the alkyne molecules to approach the active site Cu­(I/II) through the π–π interactions between alkyne and pyridyl rings of L ligands. Furthermore, open active sites were obtained for 2–4 by losing halogen anions to effectively interact with substrates alkyne. In comparison with 3 and 4, the species of copper in 2 are Cu­(II), which have a lower catalytic activity than Cu­(I) to interact with the ethynylbenzene. The active site Cu­(I) in 3 and 4 is three-coordinated and four-coordinated by N atoms and Br/I anions, which suggest that the Cu­(I) in 3 have more active sites to catalyze the A3 coupling reaction, giving higher catalytic performance for 3.

Hence, compound 3 was finally selected as the catalyst for the reaction, considering its excellent yield for expected product (, entry 3). Our next studies focused on the effect of solvent in the model reaction. Considerably low yields were observed when other solvents such as toluene, DCE, EtOH, and EtOAc were used (, entries 5–8), which may be because catalyst 3 was insoluble in these solvents. Lowering the reaction temperature to 60 or 30 °C resulted in relatively low yields of 39% or 26% (, entries 9–10). The amount of catalyst is also an important factor in the catalytic reaction. As can be seen in , by lowering the amount of catalyst, a lower yield was obtained (, entry 11), and no reaction occurred when the amount of copper catalyst was reduced to zero (, entry 12). After sufficient screening, the optimal condition eventually emerged as ethynylbenzene (1.0 mmol), formaldehyde (1.2 mmol), morpholine (1.2 mmol), and MeCN (10.0 mL) at 100 °C under microwave irradiation (, entry 3).

elements.content: Furthermore, control catalytic experiments of A3 coupling reaction were performed under the same condition. When the CuBr and L were employed as catalysts, the corresponding yields were 75% and 0 (, entries 13–14), respectively. The higher yield obtained for 3 (91%) may originate from the introduction of L into the catalytic system that altered the coordination environment of the Cu­(I) ions and the interaction between Cu­(I) centers and L in 3, resulting in the improvement of the catalytic activity of copper centers.

elements.content: After our successful efforts, we shifted our attention to the scope of A3 coupling reaction catalyzed by compound 3, and exhibits the summarized results. Surprisingly, the reaction of morpholine with both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups of p-substituted phenylacetylene afforded the desired products with high yields of 92% and 94% (5b–5c). It is noteworthy that the reactions with sterically hindered polycyclic aromatic alkynes, such as 9-ethynylphenanthrene and 1-ethynylpyrene, also proceeded smoothly to give the expected products 5d and 5e in high yields. In addition, other representative secondary amines, such as pyrrolidine and N-benzylethanamine, were also found to be suitable for this transformation and gave good to excellent yields (5f–5i). These results indicated that both the electronic effect of substituents and steric effects on the aromatic alkynes had limited influence on this copper-catalyzed three-component coupling reaction. Further to compare the catalyst dosage to the literature methods, it is worth pointing out that good to excellent yields were still obtained in the present protocol within 10 min, involving only 0.1 mol % catalyst loading without any additives.

Standard reaction conditions: alkyne (1.0 mmol), formaldehyde (1.2 mmol), amine (1.2 mmol), 3 (0.001 mmol), MeCN (10.0 mL), microwaves, 100 °C, 10 min.

Yield of the isolated products.

The products of corresponding propargylamines were characterized by 1H NMR, 13C NMR and HRMS (Figures S11–S19).

A plausible mechanism was proposed based on the experimental results and previous literature reports. As demonstrated in , the catalyst 3 initially reacts with terminal alkyne to activate the C–H bond and form a copper–acetylide A (m/z 995.1152; Figure S8). This is a very favorable step because Cu metal is well-known to give high alkynophilicity for terminal alkynes. The copper–acetylide A further reacts with B (m/z 100.0761; Figure S9), which is generated in situ from morpholine and formaldehyde, affording a coordinatively saturated intermediate C. Finally, the newly generated intermediate C dissociates to afford the expected product 5a and regenerates the catalyst. The only theoretical byproduct in the reaction is water.

Finally, the newly generated intermediate C dissociates to afford the expected product 5a and regenerates the catalyst. The only theoretical byproduct in the reaction is water.

elements.content: In this paper, four coordination polymers 1–4 have been constructed under the solvothermal reactions between CuX2 (X = NO3, Cl, Br, I) and tetra-pyridyl-functionalized calix[4]­arene (L). These compounds exhibit different architectures, such as 1D chain, double-chain and 2D networks, which demonstrates that a change in the species of anions played a crucial role in the self-assembly process. These coordination polymers have been employed in the A3 coupling reaction under microwave irradiation and 3 give the best performance, which could effectively catalyze the A3 reaction of formaldehyde with various alkynes and amines, producing the corresponding propargylamines with high yields in a short time (yields up to 94% in 10 min). Such good performance can be attributed to its abundant pyridyl rings facilitating the substrates alkyne to approach the active site of Cu­(I) through π–π interactions between the substrates and the pyridyl rings. The above observations provide further evidence that copper-based coordination polymers catalysis as an efficient catalytic platform for direct access to the important intermediates of propargylamines, by a sustainable and atom economical approach from easily accessible starting materials under mild conditions. Further studies of the construction and applications of these coordination polymers are in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this paper, four coordination polymers 1-4 have been constructed under the solvothermal reactions between CuX2 (X = NO3, Cl, Br, I) and tetra-pyridyl-functionalized calix[4]arene (L). These compounds exhibit different architectures, such as 1D chain, double-chain and 2D networks, which demonstrates that a change in the species of anions played a crucial role in the self-assembly process. These coordination polymers have been employed in the A3 coupling reaction under microwave irradiation and 3 give the best performance, which could effectively catalyze the A3 reaction of formaldehyde with various alkynes and amines, producing the corresponding propargylamines with high yields in a short time (yields up to 94% in 10 min). Such good performance can be attributed to its abundant pyridyl rings facilitating the substrates alkyne to approach the active site of Cu(I) through π-π interactions between the substrates and the pyridyl rings. The above observations provide further evidence that copper-based coordination polymers catalysis as an efficient catalytic platform for direct access to the important intermediates of propargylamines, by a sustainable and atom economical approach from easily accessible starting materials under mild conditions. Further studies of the construction and applications of these coordination polymers are in progress.

A solution of CuI2 (6 mg, 0.02 mmol), L ligand (8 mg, 0.01 mmol), and DMF (4 mL) was sealed in a 10 mL Pyrex glass tube and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. Gradual cooling at a rate of 5 °C h–1 to ambient temperature afforded the colorless blocks of 4. Yield: 7 mg (51%, based on L). Anal. Calcd for C52H44N4Cu3I3O4: C, 45.91; H, 3.26; N, 4.12. Found: C, 45.49; H, 2.98; N, 3.79. IR (KBr disc): 3061 (w), 2905 (w), 1575 (w), 1473 (m), 1456 (s), 1425 (s), 1395 (m), 1371 (m), 1317 (w), 1245 (s), 1191 (s), 1089 (m), 1052 (m), 980 (s), 944 (m), 866 (w), 800 (m), 758 (s), 698 (s), 644 (m), 620 (w), 565 (m), 511 (w) cm–1.

Results and DiscussionSynthetic and Spectral Aspects

Reactions of L ligand with Cu­(NO3)2­·3H2O and CuX2 (X = Br, I) in different solvents (MeOH/DMF for 1, MeOH/DMF for 3 and DMF for 4) at 130 °C for 3 days afforded colorless crystals of 1 (44% yield), 3 (57% yield), and 4 (51% yield), respectively. Interestingly, for compounds 1, 3, and 4, Cu­(II) was reduced to Cu­(I), which may stem from the reduction of Cu­(II) mediated by the DMF decomposition products. Similarly, reactions of CuCl2·2H2O with L ligand in EtOH produced red crystals of 2 (47% yield). To verify the valence of copper in these compounds, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) investigations were carried out. In Figure S1b, the peaks of Cu 2p3/2 at ca. 932.1 eV in 1, 3, and 4 are attributed to Cu­(I). Comparing Cu 2p XPS spectra of 1, 3, and 4 with that of 2, the higher binding energy of the Cu 2p3/2 peak at 934.3 eV in 2 is assigned to Cu­(II), accompanied by the characteristic Cu­(II) shakeup satellite peaks (938–945 eV) at 942.9 and 940.7 eV.

cln_elements.content: To investigate the thermal stability, thermogravimetric (TG) measurements of 1–4 were conducted (Figure S4). In 1, the first weight loss of 2.46% (calculated 2.99%) at the temperature range of 35–240 °C is attributed to MeOH solvent molecules. After that, further heating led to gradual decomposition of the compound. For 2–4, TG analysis indicated that they are stable up to 255 °C (2), 295 °C (3), and 305 °C (4), and then they begin to decompose.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior

To investigate the thermal stability, thermogravimetric (TG) measurements of 1-4 were conducted (Figure S4). In 1, the first weight loss of 2.46% (calculated 2.99%) at the temperature range of 35-240 °C is attributed to MeOH solvent molecules. After that, further heating led to gradual decomposition of the compound. For 2-4, TG analysis indicated that they are stable up to 255 °C (2), 295 °C (3), and 305 °C (4), and then they begin to decompose.
